Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story: I was hunched over my phone in the break room, fingers flying across the screen as I tried to finish the code sample my mentor had assigned. The deadline was in three days, but I knew if I didn’t make progress now, I’d be too exhausted after my shift. My mentor expected me to be prepared, to show initiative and responsibility. Suddenly, the shrill site-wide evacuation alarm blared through the building. My heart jumped. As a construction laborer, I knew the rules—drop everything, evacuate, and head to the muster point with the rest of the crew. No exceptions. My supervisor would notice if I lagged behind, and the team counted on everyone to follow protocol for safety. I stared at my unfinished code, the pressure from my mentor’s expectations weighing on me, while the urgent demands of the site pulled me in the opposite direction. My hands trembled as I hesitated, caught between two worlds, both demanding my full attention.
